The passage of this bill is an example of what can be achieved if there is sufficient will and strength. I know that our security and law enforcement agencies and those who recognise terrorism for the despicable scourge that it is today share my satisfaction.

The government carefully considered the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee recommendations and agreed to adopt a number of them. I am pleased that the Senate supported the government's amendments to give effect to those recommendations and agreed with our decision not to make amendments that undermine or otherwise reduce the effectiveness of the provisions dealing with associations, in particular. For example, we will not be extending the public religious worship exemption to the associations offence to include places of private worship. The blanket exemption of private worship would make enforcement difficult. It is easier for terrorist associations to occur under the cover of worship in a private setting. It should be noted that the exemption in its current form is sufficiently broad to cover any place being used for public worship. It is not confined to formal places of religious worship such as churches, temples, mosques or synagogues. Rather, the place is defined by reference to the type of activity taking place. Public religious worship takes place in the course of practising a religion whether it is in an outdoor setting or in a building. In any event, it should not be forgotten that what we are talking about here is an exemption. People genuinely engaged in private worship have nothing to fear, nor will they be relying on the exemption because they will not have met the essential elements that have to be satisfied to prove this offence. (Extension of time granted) Genuine worship will not be done with the intention of providing support to a terrorist organisation.

The Senate agreed to four amendments that give effect to three of the committee's recommendations. The first makes clear that the presumption against bail inserted into the Crimes Act by the Anti-terrorism Act of 2004 does not apply to the offence of associating with terrorist organisations. The association offence has a maximum penalty of three years imprisonment. The government agreed that the presumption should not apply to this offence because it is much less serious than the other terrorism offences which have maximum penalties of between 10 years and life imprisonment or state offences such as homicide which have a similar presumption that applies.

The government also moved amendments to broaden the exemption of the provision of legal advice or representation where that advice or representation is provided to meet the obligations and exercise rights under other antiterrorism legislation. This includes legal advice concerning ASIO warrants procedure as well as proceedings for a review of a declaration relating to issue or the failure to issue—or to demanding the surrender—of a passport or other travel document. The Senate committee also recommended that provisions dealing with the transfer of prisoners for national security reasons not proceed until there is further consultation with the states. The government believes that the better approach is to enact schedule 4 in its current form and to treat the operational security transfer procedures as a separate exercise.

It is not desirable to have no legislation in place in the coming months. However, the government agreed to an interim measure that sees the transfer of prisoner provisions confined to those prisoners convicted of, and prisoners on remand in relation to, federal offences only. Officers from the Attorney-General's Department will continue to consult with state and territory officials to develop an appropriate model for the treatment of state and territory prisoners where there is a national security concern. It is my hope that there will be no national security concerns to do with state and territory prisoners in the meantime, but it is not the first time I have had to accept a less than ideal outcome.

An exemption also applies where the association is only for the purposes of providing aid of a humanitarian nature. Recommendation 6 of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee report on the bill recommended that the government report on types of aid contemplated by exemption. I am pleased to report on behalf of the government that this exemption would cover meeting members of an organisation to treat diseases or wounds. However, it would also cover someone who is meeting or communicating with members to assess medical needs of a group—activity of that nature would still be for the purpose of providing humanitarian aid. If someone was meeting members of a terrorist organisation to provide food aid through them to a community to prevent the starvation of children, the exemption would apply. Likewise, meeting with such people for the purpose of providing vaccinations for children against serious diseases and the provision of emergency shelter for refugees would be other examples covered by the exemption. In any case, those genuinely engaged in assistance for a humanitarian purpose have nothing to fear because of the proof of knowledge requirements related to the offence. Genuine humanitarian aid will not be given with the intention of providing support to a terrorist organisation. Finally, the committee recommended that an independent review of the proposed associating offence be conducted after three years. The government is able to undertake to this chamber that the review will be conducted not in three years but rather in conjunction with the review of new security related powers which is to occur three years after the passage of those provisions in July next year.

This bill is a further contribution to the development and consolidation of counter-terrorism laws that are essential to ensure that the scourge of terrorism is confronted and dealt with. The job is not yet complete. Just as the security environment evolves and the threats we face become more sophisticated, so is the legislative framework an unfinished canvas. This bill reflects the reality that, in achieving justice, the safety and integrity of our society and its institutions must be ensured. Security is not anathema to our freedoms and liberties. Indeed, as we continue to witness the war on terror, security is absolutely an essential component of our rights and freedoms. This cannot be realised unless our security is assured. This is what this bill seeks to achieve. We can be proud of what we have achieved so far, but the job is not yet done. The Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee next week will report on another bill, the National Security Information (Criminal Proceedings) Bill 2004. I think it is a very important reform and I hope that we can reach an accommodation on that at an early stage because I think it is an important part of the measure of legislative matters that we need to comprehensively address.

talk.start.para: —I will speak only briefly on the amendments to the Anti-terrorism Bill (No. 2) 2004, and do so in the absence of the shadow Attorney-General—in many ways to repudiate what I believe was quite a malicious and unwarranted slur directed towards him by the Attorney-General. The minister suggested that the shadow Attorney-General was weak kneed because he insisted that this legislation have some examination by a parliamentary committee. I think it degrades this parliament for it to be suggested that legislation proposed by any government is immune from parliamentary scrutiny.

speech.para: We are not the clones or the creatures of the executive. We are elected here to give service to the public, and the minister ought withdraw what I believe was a scathing and completely disgraceful attack on the institutions of this parliament with that suggestion. Indeed, the minister adopted and now presents to the House, as improvements on his own legislation, measures which were inserted as a consequence of that parliamentary examination. It would have been unconscionable to have consorting offences carry with them unreviewable bail provisions. It would have been unintended and not acceptable to any person in this House that those who were the subject of investigation on ASIO related offences could not seek legal advice because their lawyers might be innocently swept up by consorting offences.

True it is that consorting offences do exist in a number of pieces of legislation. But, in every instance where consorting is introduced, we know it is perilously close to circumstances where persons who do no more than associate with those who have done wrong find themselves in jeopardy through the law. We are always careful, if we are secure in our responsibilities—not only to protect the nation from terrorism but also to respect the rights of our fellow citizens—not to allow such laws to trespass too far on the rights of our fellow citizens.

So I regret that the Attorney comes to this House—in circumstances where, as far as possible on national security and terrorism issues, we ought to seek the agreement of all members of this House, not just the major parties but all members of this House—and speaks in such a partisan way. The minister really does himself no service. He has an honourable tradition in this parliament of speaking up for broad human rights issues. He and I have shared many ventures together on that path. But, as we edge closer to an election, let us not disgrace our democracy by allowing such divisive language to be used—to suggest that you are weak kneed in the service of your community if you examine a proposal that the legislature has put forward.

It is not the case that ministers are immune from error and that the legislation that they can propose cannot be improved by such examination. I wish it had been the case that I could have asserted that all legislation I proposed when I was in a similar position of responsibility to the minister was immune from improvement, but it was not. And, when such legislation was subjected to parliamentary committees, frequently I came back to the House and acknowledged that the legislation that I had put forward on behalf of the then government had been improved as a consequence. Indeed, I believe the honourable member, the minister, actually participated in some of those committees in improving such legislation that I put forward in a number of areas which improved law enforcement in this country.

So, if I can ask, in defence of the shadow minister, who unfortunately cannot be present in the House now—in the dying hours of this parliament before adjourn, perhaps, for the last time before an election is called—that in the discourse that occurs in the lead-up to the election we be at least a little bit civil and we recognise that it is the responsibility of this parliament to examine and test legislation that is ultimately proposed to this House to ensure it is not simply passed because of an assertion by the executive of the day that it suits the appropriate circumstances but rather because it has been tested and found appropriate for the needs. (Time expired)
Question agreed to.

debate.para: The following bill was returned from the Senate without amendment or request:
Mr ABBOTT (Warringah—Leader of the House) (3.27 p.m.)—by leave—I move:

motion.para: That sessional order 84A (Interventions in the Main Committee) be adopted as a standing order with effect from the first day of the meeting of the 41st Parliament, and that the standing order be incorporated in the revised standing orders as standing order 66A.

debate.para: Just very briefly, I understand from the chairman of the Procedure Committee that this was the strong desire of the committee. The chairman herself would be here today but for illness. So, in concurrence with the committee and to continue the more active debating style which I believe has been achieved in the Main Committee, the government is very happy to move this way.

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. I.R. Causley) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —In the brief time I have available, I would like to raise a disturbing event that occurred in the new division of Gorton, which I hope to represent after the next election. This matter has had an extraordinary impact upon the whole nation, as I think it touches on one of our most elemental fears: the sudden disappearance of a child. I am speaking of course about the alleged abduction of baby Montana Barbaro at the Brimbank shopping centre last Saturday. The baby's parents, Anita Ciancio and Joe Barbaro, are obviously relieved to have their child returned to them alive and healthy, and I would like to offer my best wishes to them in their recovery from this traumatic event in the days and weeks to come.

speech.para: I would like to say how grateful for and impressed I am by the performance of the police and emergency services in this matter, in combination with the media. The emergency was resolved in an extremely short time and with a minimum of extra trauma to the parents, which does the police and emergency services nothing but credit. I would also like to take the opportunity to commend a group which we are often eager to criticise in this place—namely, the media. Both the print and the electronic media reacted swiftly by spreading accurate information about the events at Brimbank and made it possible for a local to assist the police by passing on vital information that put baby Montana back in the arms of her mother. The local to whom I refer—a jogger, Lesley, I understand—happened to be passing the derelict North Melbourne house and alerted emergency services after she heard the baby's whimpering from outside. Her first thought upon hearing the child was that it must be the baby Montana, as she had heard the news reports. I am pleased to say that the matter is proceeding through the courts with a couple currently in custody. I hope the case passes through with a minimum of fuss and stress added to that already suffered by the parents.

talk.start.para: —Before I call the honourable member for Herbert, I inform the committee that we have present in the gallery this morning members of a Commonwealth Parliamentary Association delegation from the United Kingdom. On behalf of the committee, I extend a very warm welcome to our visitors.

speech.para: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

subdebateinfo.title: Environment: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park

talk.start.para: —It is appropriate that the delegation is here with us this morning, because I would like to talk about a part of Australia that is larger in size than the United Kingdom. I refer to the 2,900 islands and reefs that make up the World Heritage listed Great Barrier Reef Marine Park system. I would like to draw your attention to a pastoral letter from the Catholic bishops of Queensland—all seven of them. The Catholic bishops of Queensland wrote this pastoral letter to say to the people of Queensland, the people of Australia and indeed the people of the world that we have to do everything that we can to protect this wonderful asset that lies off the Queensland coast. I pay a tribute to the Catholic bishops for taking the stance that they do on this protection. The document says:

quote.para: As the Catholic bishops of Queensland, we have written this letter to emphasise our shared ecological responsibility for one of the greatest national natural treasures, the Great Barrier Reef. Care for the environment and a keener ecological awareness have become a key moral issue for the Christian conscience.

speech.para: Good on them for standing up and saying that. They go on:

quote.para: We cannot realistically love our neighbours and leave out the neighbourhood in which they live, nor can we pretend to respect that neighbourhood without understanding it is a life-sustaining environment.

speech.para: Some in Queensland—indeed, some in Australia—really think that the government did the wrong thing in relation to the Representative Areas Program. For the information of the delegation here today, the government and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, which manages the reef system, embarked on a process to lock up more than 30 per cent of the reef system as representative areas so that future generations could have examples of the ecosystems of the reef and, of course, to make the reef system sustainable.

It was done on a sound scientific basis. It was questioned by those who felt that you could rape and pillage and do whatever you wanted to do in the environment—those who felt that it was their right and that the government should not interfere. The government should interfere. The government has a responsibility, as the Catholic bishops quite rightly point out, to make sure that our environment and our wonderful Great Barrier Reef are protected for future generations. I know that it has been a wonderful exercise and that we are the envy of the world in what we have been able to do. I encourage the members of the delegation to have a closer look at that to see what you might be able to do in your part of the world.

talk.start.para: —Today I wish to lodge a petition, signed in my electorate over the past two weekends by 536 people, calling on the government to provide ongoing funds to secure the long-term future of the Hunter GP access after-hours service. The petition notes that this is an essential service for our region, providing in its first year an extra 40,332 bulk-billed consultations across five clinics and professional telephone advice to more than 45,000 patients. It delivered more than 500 home visits in its first year. It has also reduced by 20 to 60 per cent walk-in patient workloads at our public hospital emergency departments.

speech.para: We have asked for ongoing funding, but we have found out this week that the Minister for Health and Ageing, Tony Abbott, has announced a one-year stay of execution. We do not know what that means and we are not very excited about it. We think it is another election bandaid—

talk.start.para: —That is right. There is no health policy, no assurance that the funding will be at the existing level—
—No health policy!
(Hon. I.R. Causley)—Order! The member for Braddon seems to interject every time he comes into the chamber. Standing order 55 applies.

—no assurance that the funding will be long-term and certainly no guarantee to the 450,000 people in our region. Rather than the hard policy work being done, we get the cheap bandaid fix. It is not good enough. The minister is arguing that a one-year extension will enable the government to properly evaluate this service. The service has been going for four years, and in its first expanded year its outcomes are outstanding. My 536 petitioners represent only the tip of the iceberg of widespread community support for the Hunter GP access after hours service. We have a message for Tony Abbott: only long-term sustainability of this essential health care service in our community will convince us that the Howard government is at all serious about our health care. We suggest that he goes back to the drawing board.

speech.para: Another example of bad policy impacting on the health of regional Australia is the outrageous decision made by the Minister for Education, Science and Training to restrict the number of HECS medical places at the University of Newcastle to just 80 per year, despite ongoing calls for an increase of 40 each year to 120. One hundred and twenty places are needed just to meet the demand of our public hospitals. It would not do anything more than that. This decision to restrict Newcastle's medical places is in spite of evidence of a strong correlation between a GP's place of training and where the GP subsequently practises. It is scandalous that the minister has refused to grant any additional medical places in a regional university which specialises in training GPs.

What is his solution for the future? Apparently he is going to leave the oversupply of doctors in Sydney and will not make any attempts to put doctors into regions with chronic shortages like Newcastle. What he and John Howard are going to do is spend millions of taxpayers' dollars to establish a private medical school in Sydney rather than put extra places into regional universities and see those regional GPs serving regions where the shortages are extreme. For the sake of my region's health and the nation's health, we do need a Labor government and very soon. (Time expired)

quote.para: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

speech.para: That the Hunter GP Access After Hours service is an essential service in the Newcastle and Hunter Region — providing an extra 40,332 bulk-billed consultations across five clinics, professional telephone advice to more than 45,000 patients and delivering more than 500 home visits in its first year of operation.
That the Hunter GP Access After Hours service has led to reductions of 20-60% in `walk-in' patient workloads at public hospital emergency departments across the Hunter region.
Despite a chronic shortage of GPs in Newcastle and the Hunter region, more than 240 doctors are working in the Hunter GP Access After Hours service.
That the Hunter GP Access After Hours is not a trial service - it is a new service providing essential health care to more than 450,000 people in the region.
That without a commitment to ongoing funds the Hunter GP Access After Hours service will have to close its doors in March 2005.

quote.para: We therefore ask the House to take urgent steps to secure ongoing funds for the Hunter GP Access After Hours service.

speech.para: from 536 citizens.

talker.name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
Dr STONE
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I wish to present a petition on behalf of 2,388 petitioners which is addressed to the Hon. the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament. The petition is from certain citizens of Australia and it reads:

quote.para: ... we the undersigned:

speech.para: totally reject any plans that expose Australia's apple and pear industry to fire blight.
Fire blight would devastate our apple trees and kill off our pear industry.
Fire blight spreads rapidly and is incurable.
We request that the House joins us in condemning the draft Biosecurity Australia interim risk assessment which recommends the importation of fresh apples from New Zealand.

Quite clearly, this is not a trade issue. Sometimes the New Zealand industry claims that all Australians in the apple and pear industry are simply afraid of some competition. This is about a deadly disease—apple and pear fire blight—which, once it has established in any country, has been found to be incurable. It leads to a significant curtailing of the vigour and thriving of the apple industry. When it comes to pears, you do not have a pear industry and fire blight.

I need to make the point that the electorate of Murray is a remote regional electorate. A lot of people had to drive several hours to put their names on this petition. Since the commencement of the petition, the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, the Hon. Warren Truss, has taken measures to substantially improve the process. Now, the draft interim risk assessments will be subject to the review of eminent persons—a scientist's review—and I am very grateful that Mr Truss has understood the issues and problems that have long been identified by stakeholders. The eminent scientists for the new process were announced just yesterday. That process is going to give us a lot more confidence in the way that the science will be dealt with. A draft interim risk assessment will be developed in the first instance followed by an independent scientist review.

In the electorate of Murray, we have more than 90 per cent of the pear industry of Australia. It is the underpinning of a manufactured fruit industry. Without our pear industry we will not see great companies like SPC Ardmona, who are one of the last Australian owned fruit manufacturing companies, produce magnificent product for both domestic and export markets. One of our concerns is the fruit labelling issue. The CER agreement means that New Zealand apples would not even be labelled as coming from New Zealand. So, if they were allowed to come in, Australians could not even demonstrate with their eating habits their concern about that fruit being in the country and they could not take special care with the cores, peels and any remains after they had eaten the fresh fruit because it would not be labelled as coming from New Zealand. In tabling this petition I wish to say that this is a very important issue. (Time expired)

quote.para: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that we the undersigned:

speech.para: Totally reject any plans that expose Australia's apple and pear industry to Fire Blight.
Fire Blight would devastate our apple trees and kill off our pear industry.
Fire Blight spreads rapidly and is incurable.
We request that the House joins us in condemning the draft Biosecurity Australia's Interim Risk Assessment which recommends the importation of fresh apples from New Zealand.
from 2,388 citizens.

talk.start.para: —I would like to comment on and congratulate the Penguin Skills Centre, which is located at Penguin High School in my electorate, overlooking the beautiful Bass Strait. The Penguin Skills Centre is a special place that promotes, nurtures and delivers lifelong learning. It fulfils all the needs for lifelong learning that are stated in the Tasmanian government's A State of Learning objectives. It has 130 students, primarily adult learners, under the coordination of Liz Ryan. It has one full-time VET coordinator/manager and five part-time and several sessional trainers.

speech.para: It delivers a variety of important courses taken up by adults who are returning to learning, in most cases. It offers certificates II and III in community services, aged care and child care and certificates I and II in visual arts and contemporary crafts. It delivers a very special mentoring program in the community, and it offers certificates I and II in information technology. It also provides a program of basic IT enabling skills for older workers, of which there are 40 participants for 2004-05. There is a competitive bids IT certificate II. They provide certificate training places at both Wilmot and Sheffield, which are spread far and wide from Penguin. It also provides an ANTA innovative literacy project. Some of the mentoring programs, particularly provided by Aboriginal groups, play a very important role.

Penguin Skills Centre has also received local, state and federal recognition for its courses. I publicly record my appreciation of the Penguin Skills Centre, particularly to its coordinator Liz Ryan. But I am concerned as I have heard there are proposals in the wings that they may phase out certificate III level training packages at skills centres throughout Tassie—and that of course would include at the Penguin Skill Centre. I believe that TAFE Tasmania will become the controlling body. I am concerned about that because I think it undermines the very nature of continuing learning and lifelong learning in a community, where an organisation such as the Penguin Skills Centre has built up a tremendous network of connections and connectivity with its community, employers and local groups. I would hate to see that undermined and the viability of these skills centres threatened.

talk.start.para: —On 17 July several hundred Bundaberg district residents gathered at the Winfield State School to celebrate the 90th birthday of a truly remarkable and gracious lady, Mrs Ethel Grills. The day was made even more special with the attendance of Mrs Grill's loving family and friends, many of whom travelled considerable distances to attend the day, coming from Brisbane, Miles, Tara and New South Wales centres. The birthday celebrations were held in the fashion of an `old school picnic' under the majestic fig trees in the school grounds.

speech.para: There was a fitting ambience in marking the big day in these beautiful school grounds, because Mrs Grills was one of the community's longest residing locals and had a longstanding involvement with the school throughout 78 years of living in the district. In fact, it was Mrs Grill's father-in-law, Ernest Jacob Grills, who originally donated to the Queensland Education Department in the 1920s the five acre parcel of land on which the school stands. For many years Mrs Grills continued the family's association with the school, serving on school committees, and teaching sewing to the students for 29 years. She used to travel to those lessons on a bicycle across very rough roads; that is a mark of her dedication. Many of those same sewing students returned to the school to help Mrs Grills celebrate her big day.

It was quite clear by the turnout of people at the party that Mrs Grills gave her heart and soul to the Winfield community, to the point that many guests were invited to make a donation to the Winfield Community Hall Fund, one of her family's pet projects. Mrs Grills and her late husband, Ernest John, raised their eight children on a mixed enterprise farm. It is an interesting aside that, after her husband's death in 1981, Mrs Grills took over the duties of collecting and reporting data for the Bureau of Meteorology. For 22 years Mrs Grills provided the general public with accurate rainfall figures and the like, which is vital to a community such as Winfield, heavily reliant on rain for agriculture.

On the day, I was pleased to be able to read a congratulatory letter from the Prime Minister, while Burnett Shire Mayor, Ray Duffy, read out a letter of commendation from the Bureau of Meteorology. Although Mrs Grills moved to a care facility in Bundaberg earlier this year, I know she greatly enjoyed coming back to Winfield to celebrate her birthday amongst her family and friends. Her children, Robert, Melvyn, Graham, Ferna, Delphene, Clifford, Jeffery and Christine as well as grandchildren—all of whom are still living in the Bundaberg district—deserve genuine commendation for their efforts in organising this community event. In saluting Ethel Grills, a great Australian, let me say it was a pleasure to be there.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—Order! In accordance with standing order 275A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

motion.para: That the Main Committee do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I would like to speak today in the adjournment debate about a survey on health that I recently carried out in my electorate of New England. The survey, comprising six questions, was answered by 8,380 people within the electorate. I thank those people for the effort that they put in not only in responding to the survey but also in writing letters, many of which related personal experiences with respect to the delivery of health care—the problems, the good points et cetera. As I said, 8,380 people responded to the survey, which is about a 16 per cent response rate on the number of surveys that we sent out. I think it was an excellent response; it was similar to that received to a survey on Telstra a couple of years ago.

speech.para: I would like to go through the results of that survey. As many members would know, there is currently a merger process going on with some of the area health services within New South Wales. Even though it is essentially a state issue it could have some federal implications further down the track. The merger process that was under way at the time was between the New England Area Health Service and the Hunter Area Health Service. Asked whether they supported that merger, 93 per cent of the respondents said no, 2.3 per cent said yes and 4.7 per cent were undecided.

The other issues that were canvassed were in relation to dental health. On the question `Should dental health work be covered by Medicare?' 92 per cent of the respondents said yes, five per cent said no and three per cent were undecided. That is a very appropriate question to ask at this particular time. At the recent budget, the government made some positive moves in the right direction to include some aspects of dental care under Medicare. I do not think that has gone far enough. I understand that the Labor Party are moving in a further direction in relation to that as well. I would encourage both the government and the opposition to look very carefully at the results of this survey and particularly at the issue of dental care. If we do not look after oral health we are going to end up with some enormous expenses further down the track in terms of bodily health. It amazes me that we have not included dental health in Medicare in the past.

Bulk-billing is another significant issue. I asked the question, `Does your local doctor bulk-bill?' and 34.6 per cent said yes, 58.2 per cent said no and 7.2 per cent did not know, so obviously they are in good health and are not going to their doctors. Those figures are quite alarming. I ask the Minister for Health and Ageing to release the bulk-billing figures. I know that they have changed the rulings on that recently. I think the December ruling was that about 47 per cent of New England doctors were bulk-billing. This survey indicates that it is not improving, and we need to take these figures on board.

I asked, `Which level of government do you want in charge of our hospitals?' I apologise for this question because I think it was actually interpreted in slightly different ways. I know that debate is taking place at the moment between the Commonwealth health minister and the state ministers. The answer is interesting, but, because of the way the question was framed, I do not know whether we can take a lot from it. A lot of people in New England are very upset with the Carr Labor government at the moment, with the health merger, and that had some impact on the way in which this question was answered. Forty-one per cent said that they would rather see the federal government take charge of our health system, 20 per cent said the state government, 24 per cent said the local government—that is where there is a bit of a merging of the question—and 15 per cent were undecided.

Another issue of great importance—and I highlight this one—is that people would vote for an increase in the Medicare levy from 1.5 per cent to two per cent. Eighty-one per cent of people said that they would vote for that. Ninety-one per cent said that they wanted the University of New England to be the facility for a medical school and allied health services in order to train and retain doctors and allied health service professionals within country areas. (Time expired)

talker.name: Kelly, Jackie, MP
Miss JACKIE KELLY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —Today I would like to raise an issue for which I have fought very long and hard—and very well, I think—in my local area, and that is the preservation of the environmentally sensitive lands at the ADI site. Since Labor first wanted to sell the land, it has been a sore point for the constituents in my area. This government commissioned an Australian Heritage Commission report on the land, and over 850 hectares were listed by the Australian Heritage Commission. Just prior to the last election, the then environment minister, Senator Robert Hill, announced the preservation of another 300-odd hectares on the site, so that the entire site would be protected by an AHC listing.

speech.para: Since that time the remainder of the site has gone forward in the development process. Certainly I fought to preserve some sporting precincts within the area because there was so much environmental land. The point of environmental land is that it is environmental land and you cannot have a barbecue, play footy or ride your BMX bike or skateboard there. You certainly cannot take a trail bike through it. The area was always slated for urban infill because it is totally surrounded by urban areas. In Western Sydney we are in the burbs—pram city, as I call it. It is a place of children. If children see a park like that, with an open green space and a creek, they are going to climb under the fence, get inside and have a great time. They are going to come home to mum dirty and muddy up to the knees, they will not really tell mum where they have been and they will get cleaned up and have dinner. In the meantime, some very sensitive land has been destroyed.

It is important that the existing fence remain. I propose that inside that fence we erect another fence—a vermin-proof fence which goes three feet down into the ground and prevents dogs and other vermin from burrowing underneath the fence. It should go up six feet and have railings that project out towards the existing fence. That should have about three strands of barbed wire along it as well as two electrified wires. This prevents cats and other vermin getting over the top of the fence. Within the environmental precinct you would also run your ducks and white chooks so that, if any vermin do get inside, they normally catch the ducks and chooks first. You can then see that you have an intruder. Over time you rebuild your natural flora and fauna. With that comes the birdlife and nesting. You end up with a real state-of-the-art environmental precinct and you preserve and enhance all of those values that we have fought so hard to preserve on those 850 hectares. It is critical that the environmental precinct stays fenced.

A wonderful private enterprise example of this is Warrawong sanctuary, north of Adelaide. I visited Warrawong some time back during my fight on this thing. The vision that I have had is that private enterprise would move into the conservation area. Always leaving conservation to government is a tall ask. At the end of the day we have only so much money that we take off the taxpayers. Generally things like medicine, health and education get higher priorities than perhaps the environment does. We slice off these big areas and leave them unattended, but the National Parks and Wildlife Service is poorly funded to do its job over such a huge area. Consequently our kids, our trail bike riders and other people jump the bollards, come in through the parks and destroy some very sensitive areas. In the Warrawong example you actually have a paid entry point and local residents get so many passes a year to bring visitors in. You can generate wooden boardwalks above the environmentally sensitive areas and really have a superlative tourist attraction right here in our own backyard. I really recommend fencing of the environmental land in the state management plan. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to take the opportunity to say a few words today about the 2004 Olympic Games in Athens. As we all know, tomorrow at some time in the very early hours of the morning, the official opening ceremony is due to get under way. I am absolutely certain that, in the next two weeks, Australia and the rest of the world will be absolutely transfixed by the action taking place in Athens. For us here in Australia, the excitement and interest will be greater, I think, than elsewhere, not only because just four years ago we experienced similar excitement and world attention when we staged the very successful Sydney 2000 Games but also because Australia is home to a very large Greek community. In particular, my home town of Melbourne has legendary status as the city with the greatest proportion of the Greek diaspora.

speech.para: Australia's participation and involvement in the Athens Games is very much defined by the special relationship that this country has with Greece. When I visited the Mayor of Athens, Dora Bakoyiannis, last October, she was very keen to convey to me and through me to the House the sentiments and affection of the people of Greece for the people of Australia. She made the point to me last year that `we are like family' and there is no need for Australians to feel insecure and unsafe about travelling to Greece. Of course, I took the liberty of reassuring the mayor that most Australians felt comfortable about travelling to Greece, and certainly those lucky enough to be attending the games were very much looking forward to the experience.

We are all keenly aware that the Olympic Games are being held against a backdrop of international terrorism and world conflict. I think everybody knows that. I can assure this House, as the mayor of Athens and other Greek government and Olympic officials have—and indeed as have our own Olympic officials—that the Greeks have made security their No. 1 priority. They have invested lots of time and, might I say, money—millions and millions of euros—and effort into doing everything they possibly can to keep participants, particularly athletes, and that includes our athletes, safe and secure.

I know that our athletes have been looking forward to the games and to the competition. We have read about the efforts and the very hard training that go into getting ready for the Olympic Games. They have now all left this country for the games—I certainly hope they are all there—taking with them our hopes and our aspirations. I would like to take this opportunity to offer them my support and my electorate's support and good wishes, and we wish them the best of luck. It is very important during a time of some apprehension, given the international circumstances, to concentrate on the positives. I am sure that our athletes, as well as the Australian Olympic Committee, want to focus on winning medals rather than being distracted by fear. I know that they have not been distracted from the main game, and I am also confident that the Greek authorities are well placed to provide the security and safety for the athletes of the world, including our own athletes.

The 2004 Athens Olympics will also be great games. They will be particularly special, I think, because they are returning back to their place of birth. I think no city in the world, despite all the tremendous efforts, can ever recreate the atmosphere of the original place of birth. It is a shame that our colleagues from the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association from Britain have left the chamber. But given that they were here, I want to take the opportunity to say that it is indeed a great pity and quite sad that the British government and the British Museum were unable to assist in the reconstitution of the Parthenon marbles. I know for a fact that in Greece, in the worldwide movement and in Australia in particular there is support for that to occur. I look forward to speaking to the private member's motion of the member for Kooyong in the next sitting on the reconstitution of the Parthenon marbles. I know that this House will support that reconstitution. It is a shame that the 2004 Games in Athens will not see the Parthenon marbles reconstituted to Greece.

In any case, the theme of the Athens Games is the unification of civilisations. They are celebrating the world's diversity and rich cultural heritage. I am sure that we Australians can relate very well to that theme. We often celebrate our cultural diversity, which is the cornerstone of our multicultural identity. As I said, Australia has a very special place in the minds of the people of Athens. In fact, when the games ended in Sydney in 2000, many Australians followed the flame to Athens. Australian expertise and knowledge has been involved in assisting in the preparation for 2004, including people like Michael Knight and Peter Ryan and the many volunteers— (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I wish to slam the cynicism and opportunism of the Labor Party's road funding gestures in my electorate that occurred several weeks ago. I have spoken on this issue in the House before. After this year's federal budget, it was announced as part of the AusLink program that $150 million would be spent on the Mandurah bypass in my electorate and on the completion of the Kwinana Freeway, which coincidently is in the electorate of Brand. That was the figure that the state government and the minister, Alannah MacTiernan, had asked for as the 50 per cent share for completing this freeway and building the Mandurah bypass, which is crucial to transport and infrastructure not only in my electorate and the Peel region but in the south-west of Western Australia. Senator Ian Campbell, the then Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads, announced this money in Mandurah. Following this announcement, I said that the money was readily available—it was in the forward estimates; it was in the budget—and could be accessed forthwith.

speech.para: However, the minister of the state Labor government, who have to build these roads—we give them the money and they do the job—said, `No, we don't want to build this road until 2009.' As a result of pressure by the then minister, Senator Ian Campbell, she brought that date back to 2008, and then even suggested 2007. We believe, on advice from Main Roads Western Australia, that this road could be built and begun in early 2006. As a result, benefits would flow to the people of Western Australia and the regions that I have described. However, something happened a few weeks ago that was quite baseless politicking, without any sincerity to it. The federal Labor transport spokesman, Martin Ferguson, the member for Batman, arrived in Mandurah along with the member for Brand and the candidate for Canning—we are not sure if she is still the candidate for Canning after this morning's news or whether she has resigned—along with the state minister for transport. They said that a federal Labor government would give $170 million to this project—an extra $20 million.

We are now in a Dutch auction for the Mandurah bypass. I wonder why they are going to need an extra $20 million. One can only surmise that, if you allow the time for a road to be built to blow out by two years, the road will cost a lot more to build. If they actually got on and built this road when Main Roads said they could build it, it could be done for the figure they asked for, which was $150 million—$75 million for the completion of the freeway and $75 million for the bypass. But no. The state minister—who is part of the guilty party on this—then said the state government would up the ante and put an extra $20 million in too. Here is extra expenditure of $40 million on a road for which they asked for $150 million to build. It could be built for that amount; Main Roads have costed it out at that now. What is the problem? The problem is, as I have described, the delay. They do not want to do it until at least two years later.

The other problem is that the state transport minister is in the process of building a very expensive railway from Perth to Mandurah. The cost started off at about $1.8 billion. It is now $2.3 billion and rising. All the road and transport infrastructure funding is being sucked into this railway, which by some estimates will take only 400 people a day between Mandurah and Perth. It has been estimated by some that you could actually give those 400 people a brand-new Hyundai car every three years and a fuel card and it would still cost less over a period of time than building the Mandurah railway. I am not against the Mandurah railway; it is just the wrong route and the cost has just blown out.

But let us get back to Martin Ferguson, the member for Batman, going down there. One of the other reasons why the cost is blowing out is the collusive tendering arrangements that the state government has entered into. By way of example, I mention the speech I made in this place not so long ago about the Tonkin Highway. The cost of that was estimated to be $105 million. It is now $145 million. Why? Because, as I said at the time, Leightons and their associated companies got together and settled on a price which saw it blow out from $105 million to $145 million. I am urging the state government to stop playing games with the Mandurah bypass, to stop playing games with building the freeway and to get on and put the necessary infrastructure into the region. Be serious about it now: build the road and stop the cynical opportunism about the Mandurah bypass. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Environment: Mandatory Renewable Energy Targets Scheme

talk.start.para: —I became aware of Hydro Tasmania's response to the government's so-called energy white paper recently and I found it very sobering. It reinforces what I have had to say on a number of occasions in this House on the issue of lack of support for renewables in the government's energy white paper. I would like to share some of Hydro Tasmania's responses to the energy white paper. I note that Hydro Tasmania recognise the importance of fossil fuels in meeting Australia's energy needs—as we all do—and recognise that, like elsewhere throughout the world, renewable energy will also contribute significantly to meeting our growing energy demands. They are not mutually exclusive, as some would have us believe. Hydro Tasmania recognise that MRET has been retained but are concerned that the key findings of the government's Tambling report—that is, in terms of target size and duration—have been ignored. I think that was the great shock in this energy white paper. It shocked Minister Kemp so much that he resigned.

speech.para: Hydro Tasmania welcomes the funding opportunities for renewable energy but is concerned that, without a strengthened MRET and emissions trading, the market required to deploy new and developing technologies will only exist overseas—not here but overseas. Hydro Tasmania's $1.4 billion renewable energy program needs a strengthened MRET; otherwise it will stall by 2007 due to a lack of commercial viability and a restricted market. This is the same for all other renewable energy developers. It is okay to provide funding for research and development for the development of greater efficiencies, particularly at the up-front stage of developing renewable energies but, if you do not have a market, what is the incentive? I cannot see the logic to it. Hydro Tasmania also recognises, like all of us, that significant regional development, manufacturing, jobs and investment will not proceed unless MRET levels are strengthened. Already the industry is in a state of high uncertainty. Haywards Engineering, for instance, are involved in the base works for the wind turbines, and Vestas, which is located in my electorate, was very close to introducing a blade manufacturing plant. That is on hold and has a very uncertain future.

One of the main areas of concern—and I have tried to raise this in the House before and publicly in my newsletter, which is now doing the rounds through the electorate—relates to the exaggerated claims of electricity price increases to households if an MRET is increased. Some of the figures thrown out by Senators Abetz and Colbeck are absolutely outrageous. Comparing oranges with apples and a whole European energy system with Tasmania's is quite ludicrous and illogical, but that is the type of stuff they are pumping out as apologists for this government's failure to support renewable energy in the energy white paper. I would like to present some figures from ABARE which basically show that the national average household quarterly electricity bill forecast for 2010, without an MRET—and my colleague and friend the member for Franklin will be interested in this—is $261.85. ABARE's figures show that the increased quarterly cost due to an MRET—for instance, continuing the target of 9,500 gigawatt hours—would be $3.07, or a rise of 1.2 per cent. A total of 20,000 gigawatt hours or a five per cent MRET, as the Labor Party is advocating, on 2010 figures would be a quarterly increase of $8.20, or a rise of three per cent. If it went to 32,000 gigawatt hours or a 10 per cent MRET, which is not our policy, there would be an increase of $13.12 a quarter for a household electricity bill, or a five per cent increase. We know that by 2016 the cost comparisons between coal, gas, wind and energy will overlap if the wind industry is allowed to grow— (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Last week I spoke about the announcement of a medical facility at the Shoalhaven campus of the University of Wollongong. Today I want to raise the issue once again, because since then I have become aware of an attempt to falsely claim credit for that announcement. In my earlier speech I acknowledged those who contributed towards the realisation of this project worth $10 million. Let me repeat my words. I said:

quote.para: I wish to congratulate Vice-Chancellor Gerard Sutton. I also wish to thank the Divisions of General Practice and all our GPs, who were totally united in working on this project. I also want to thank Professor Don Iverson, whose dream it was to have a medical school at the Shoalhaven campus in Gilmore, and Canio Fierravanti-Wells from the university.

speech.para: They were the significant players who helped bring this initiative to fruition. I am not so crass as to not acknowledge anybody else's contribution, but last Friday when I was speaking to the media my breath was taken away by what I heard—and I later had this confirmed from university sources.

In medical terms there is a condition called Munchausen's syndrome, sometimes referred to as `factitious disorder'. Factitious literally means contrived, and the meaning could hardly be more apt. People with factitious disorder are great con men or con women, although what they obtain through their conning most people would far rather not have. It was named in honour of a German baron who was a famous liar, so imagine my surprise and contempt when a comment was made by the member for Cunningham claiming undeserved credit for contributing to the medical school's success. I would like to know how his reasoning allowed him to do so.

Even after working on this project for a long time—in fact, years—not once was I made aware that the member for Cunningham was involved to any degree. What he did do was indulge in negativity, saying it would never happen, leading people to believe we had failed to deliver and hoping to achieve a political hit on this government. I even went to the extent of asking the member twice to stop his negativity and say something positive for a change. In fact, his constituents need to know that not once—and I repeat, not once—has he ever voted with the government on any issue, even when it would have been of benefit to his constituents. Yet, when this government introduced this innovative and exciting proposal for the Shoalhaven campus of the University of Wollongong, he wanted to take the credit.

What he has actually done could be seen as a form of plagiarism—taking credit for someone else's efforts, and brazenly so. Is the member so desperate for recognition that he needs to hunt publicity in someone else's electorate? I think it is sad that the member must resort to such devices. It has certainly lowered my respect for him as a representative of the people of Cunningham. The act is opportunistic at best. I urge the member to approach the people he made the claim to and apologise for his cheap, shabby behaviour. It diminishes the genuine work of other people and denigrates the reputation of this House. In fact, I wish the member for Cunningham were present in the Main Committee chamber so I could ask him what he has done for his electorate apart from making untrue speeches.

talk.start.para: —Many in this place volunteer to serve in the armed forces to gain a better understanding of the excellent work being done by those serving our country both here in Australia and overseas in the various military domains. I decided to volunteer in another area of service to better understand the superb work done by other workers—workers in our child-care sector.

speech.para: As a teacher in my former life and as someone who has always been very interested in the education of young people, I have long been an advocate for the child-care sector. When I was a teacher, it used to annoy me that when politicians visited my school they came out and, especially in the early childhood area, looked at what was happening, saw the prep, grade 1 and grade 2 teachers, saw that things were going along swimmingly and assumed that there was no great need to further resource the early childhood sector. However, as teachers know, this is the area where you are actually building the foundations. To expect teachers to cater for the individual differences of anywhere up to 25—in some cases even more—young children and provide them with the necessary knowledge, experiences and challenges is very time consuming, very difficult and, in some cases, very frustrating. In the preschool and early childhood sector it is even more challenging and difficult.

So, as I say, I volunteered to work in a child-care centre. I had a meeting with some child-care activists—Mel Webb, Hester Van Niekerk and Roseanne Wardrop—who told me of the campaign being run to alert not only the public but also those in politics to the need to support workers in their struggle to gain recognition in the community, to gain a better wage structure and to develop a more professional education basis for the work that they do.

So the other week in the early hours of the morning, at half past seven, I rocked up to the Howrah Beach Childcare Centre and experienced life for 4½ hours working in that wonderful child-care centre. I met the parents bringing their kids in. I saw the wonderful work that the centre workers did in welcoming the children and parents into the centre. It amazed me, as a former teacher, to see the knowledge that they had of the children and the interest that they took in them. As a bit of an oldie sitting down and reading stories with the kids, I was soon struck by the fact that there are no men working at the centre. In fact, there are very few men working in the child-care sector. I was a bit of a novelty sitting down and reading the kids books. They played with my moustache and one said, `I've a grandfather who's got one of those things.' I helped set up the playground equipment and I fed the kids. I baulked at changing the nappies in the babies room; I have not got around to that as yet. I quickly gained an experience of the wonderful work and amazing preparation that the child-care workers do to enable them to support, challenge and nurture the children as they prepare them for later life.

As I said at the outset, many of us in this place volunteer to work in the various forms of the armed services. I would issue a challenge to politicians to work at child-care centres. I know it would be seen as a bit cynical at the moment, in the lead-up to the election, if we all volunteer to work in child-care centres, but I have long had an association with early childhood and I am going to volunteer, even if the election is on, to work at the Howrah Beach Childcare Centre and also at some of the country child-care centres in my electorate, just to give the workers the support and encouragement that they so richly deserve in the wonderful work that they do in educating our children at that early age.

subdebateinfo.title: Forde Electorate: Defence Personnel and Veterans

talk.start.para: —At a time when our Australian defence personnel are doing a tremendous job overseas and have a great deal of community support, I want to take the time today to reflect on some local achievements by our defence personnel, our veterans and our local RSLs. Last weekend I was pleased to join with the Minister for Defence, Robert Hill; the Chief of Army, Peter Leahy; and our Governor-General, Michael Jeffrey, as the Australian Army Intelligence Corps was presented at Canungra with the high honour of the Governor-General's Banner. I know first-hand what a fine group of people work at the Canungra Land Warfare Centre and how important the defence community is to the area. The Canungra Land Warfare Centre has a proud history, and its new intelligence centre is a tremendous addition.

speech.para: The Governor-General's Banner is traditionally awarded for great service or efficiency. This custom began with the presentation of 20 King's banners in 1904 for service in the Boer War. Established in 1907, the Australian Army Intelligence Corps predates its United Kingdom and United States of America equivalents and has done service in both World Wars, Korea, the Malayan Emergency, Borneo, Vietnam and, more recently, Somalia, Rwanda, Bougainville, the Gulf War, East Timor, the Solomon Islands and Iraq.

Canungra's $17 million Defence Intelligence Training Centre became operational this year. Congratulations to everyone at Canungra and, again, a big thankyou to our defence personnel for the fine job they do in these challenging times. I would also like to give my thanks to the many hundreds of people in the Canungra community who came out and witnessed this very special and big event in our community.

I was also pleased to host a special presentation recently of certificates of appreciation to our local veterans and their families. These certificates, part of the government's Saluting Their Service program, provide important recognition for those who served our country in war. I would like to record the names here today of those who were presented with certificates, including family members accepting on behalf of those who served who are no longer with us. They were: Stephen Armbrust of North Tamborine, Thomas Bevan of Beaudesert, Gloria Buchanan of Mount Gravatt, John Damon of Eagle Heights, Graham and Fay Davis of Beaudesert, Ellen Doak of Beaudesert, Barbara Donaldson of Jimboomba, Frederick Franklin of Mount Tamborine, Elizabeth Hayward of Mundoolum, Terrence Kassulke of Beaudesert, Elizabeth Laughton of Calamvale, John Arthur Marshall of Eagle Heights, Jack Valentine McNamara of Mount Warren Park, Robert George Millar of Waterford West, Frederick John Ward of Bethania and Mary Waight of Beaudesert. I also presented the National Service Medal, recognising the unique contribution of our national servicemen who served between 1951 and 1992, to Barbara Donaldson of Jimboomba, for her late husband, and to Douglas Panten of Loganholme. I was also privileged to be able to present the Australian Service Medal to Gary Fern of Beenleigh.

Finally, while we are on the topic of our veterans, I want to congratulate two local RSLs which recently received funding grants. The Rathdowney subbranch will receive $4,000 to restore the Rathdowney Memorial Gates, and the Beaudesert subbranch will receive $3,000 to build a memorial wall at the club to display local wartime memorabilia. Both these organisations do a fantastic job for their members and the general community. These two projects, funded under the Howard government's Saluting Their Service program, will help ensure that future generations remember the debt of gratitude we owe to those who served us well. These grants come on top of grants earlier this year to Boonah and Canungra RSLs. I am very fortunate to have both a strong ex-service community in the wider electorate and a tremendous service community at Canungra. I feel very honoured and very privileged to represent this great electorate of Forde.

talk.start.para: —Today I provide the House with a progress report with regard to the delivery of three essential services in my electorate. They are all matters that I have raised on various occasions in the past. The first concerns the Thomastown office of the North-East Migrant Resource Centre which I officially opened on 29 June. The new office of the North-East MRC will provide valuable assistance to the many new arrivals in ethnic communities in the city of Whittlesea, which is long overdue. I congratulate the migrant resource centre on this initiative.

speech.para: The second service is the Whittlesea Community Legal Centre, officially opened last Friday by my former federal parliamentary colleague the state Attorney-General Rob Hulls at the Community Information Whittlesea office in Epping. In the few weeks this legal service has been operating, it has absolutely demonstrated the unmet need for legal services which existed. The service is booked out through to the end of the month. The community legal education offices have been busy, and a team of volunteers has been attracted to assist the service. Outreach services to Whittlesea township and Mill Park will commence shortly. I congratulate the state government on funding this service. I congratulate Community Information Whittlesea and Kildonan Family Service as the auspice consortia partners. Sadly, it is becoming clear, even at this early stage, that the resources available are outstripped by the demand. I again call upon the federal government to join in partnership with the local community and the state government and provide their share of the resources that are required to ensure that the Whittlesea Community Legal Centre further develops.

The third proposal I raise is the after-hours GP clinic at the Northern Hospital. I remind the House that, in the run-up to the last election, on the basis of indications from the Commonwealth government through the then minister, Minister Wooldridge, of Commonwealth support for the project, the Bracks state government funded a purpose-built facility which now awaits an announcement from the Howard government of the recurring funding required. The accident and emergency centre at the Northern Hospital is one of the busiest in Victoria. In excess of 60 per cent of those that present at the accident and emergency centre are triaged as category 4 or 5, indicating that they could easily be treated by a general practitioner.

The federal government should recognise that the majority of these patients are a Commonwealth responsibility and should fund this project. A proposal has been before the government since December 2002, and in February this year the member for McEwen indicated that a decision would be made soon. It is the local residents in the federal seats of Scullin and McEwen who suffer, as they are the greatest users of the Northern Hospital. This is about freeing up the resources of the Northern Hospital and assisting it to meet the unmet demand for more after-hours GP services. It is not about taking patients from existing services.

Labor has already announced funding for a Medicare team to work at the currently unused clinic at the Northern Hospital, adding to the role already provided by local GPs helping to ease the pressure on the hospital's emergency department. The Northern Division of General Practice, an industry body, advocated for an after-hours GP clinic as the sort of service that is needed by the Northern Hospital. I believe it is time that Minister Abbott acted. He should act because the community is still waiting. The Northern Hospital's resources should be freed up. The minister should make a decision and he should make it soon—sooner rather than later. This is what the community demands to ensure that the services provided by the Northern Hospital continue to develop to the high standard that the community has expected from other services and that it now recognises that the hospital can provide.

talk.start.para: —Over the last several months, there has been a push to get a veterinary school for James Cook University in Townsville. Part of that veterinary school would also be located in the tablelands of North Queensland. It is a very good proposal, but it is only part of the vision that I have for the next major step that will take James Cook University forward to be one of the top five universities in Australia and one of the leading universities in the world. There is an outstanding opportunity right now for James Cook University, which we must seize, we must implement, and which the government must help implement.

speech.para: I am very strongly supportive of James Cook University's vision to become the nucleus of a tropical research and development headquarters for Northern Queensland and indeed the world. This vision seeks to bring together on one site as many as possible of the R&D providers of the region, with a view to creating the largest aggregation of tropically focused researchers in the world. In the broad context, there is a general strategic goal for JCU, both in Townsville and in Cairns, to act as the major facilitator to encourage a greater degree of collaboration and, where appropriate, proximity between the university and as many as possible of the various state, Commonwealth and industry based research agencies in our region.

The prerequisite for the practical implementation of this vision is the appropriately designed special-purpose building to be located on the Townsville campus of James Cook University, close to the medical school and the Townsville Hospital; the schools of public health and tropical medicine, tropical biology and engineering; and the current site of the CSIRO Davies Laboratory. Detailed costings are to be prepared, but I estimate that something in the order of $20 million will be required to provide the necessary capital infrastructure to allow JCU to take advantage of and implement this vision.

We are talking about co-locating the CSIRO on campus. The EcoGrid consortium aims at JCU. We are talking about a marine science consolidation at JCU and new tropical science courses at JCU—and this is where veterinary science fits into the picture, along with tropical agricultural science. There is the sugar connection, through SRI and BSES. The DPI&F and other state research agencies—and of course the successor entity to the rainforest and reef CRCs—will be involved.

There is huge potential for this at our university. James Cook University is the natural site for the development of a concentration of tropical science and innovation expertise and capacity in Queensland. It is one of only 13 Australian universities to rank in the Shanghai Jiao Tong University's top 500. It ranks second in Australia in terms of actual over expected citation performance. It ranks second in the world amongst specialist marine science institutes for a number of publications. Amongst tropical universities, JCU ranks in the top dozen or so in the world.

JCU has positioned itself well over the last few years. Its broad strategic goals are in line with some of the major recent strategic initiatives at both state and federal levels. Its mission statement emphasises its tropical focus. Its vision statement sets the target of becoming by 2010 one of the world's top five universities with a focus on life and living in the tropics. Some of this has already been achieved. I am doing everything I can to enable James Cook University to make its vision a reality. It is a tremendous step forward to think that JCU can get this huge centre of gravity of world tropical science on its campus in Townsville.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak about a very important issue in my electorate, and that is the lack of child-care places. I have spoken about this on many occasions—as many as 30 times in my eight years as a member of this parliament—but recent events in my electorate have highlighted this problem even further. The Kings Langley preschool and its long day care centre have received notification from the state Department of Community Services advising that the existing before and after school care service will have to close before 20 August. This means that parents of some 50 children will have to find alternative before and after school care in an area that already faces long waiting lists and limited places.

speech.para: It appears that under child-care regulations the number of school-age children attending before and after school care must not exceed 10 per cent of the licensed preschool places unless separate facilities are provided to care for these children. The number of school-age children attending far exceeds this number. It also appears, though, that these arrangements have been in place at Kings Langley preschool for over 10 years. This decision by DOCS is within the regulations and is in the interest of the welfare of the children, but nevertheless it will cause hardship for many parents who, with both parents working, will have insufficient time to find alternative before and after school care.

I have written to the state Minister for Community Services asking for the closure of this service to be delayed until the end of the current school year or until a new service can be established, which I understand is what the local primary school wishes to do. The difficulty that the parents of these children have in finding alternative places highlights a problem that has existed in Greenway since the first year of the Howard government. In the 1996-97 budget, there was an $820 million cut in child care, which led to increased fees, reduced child-care assistance and the closure of several services. At that time, the closures occurred in Greenway, Seven Hills, Marayong, Riverstone and Blacktown. Moving forward to the present day, we find that the result of this short-sighted policy of funding cuts is expressed in the closure of Kings Langley before and after school care.

talk.start.para: (Hon. D.G.H. Adams)—Order!

—At the Senate estimates committee hearing in June last year, it was stated that there was a shortage of before and after school care in the Blacktown local government area of over 1,000 places. This was well in excess of any local government area in Australia. The next highest shortfall was in the neighbouring area of Holroyd, which had almost half that number—some 590 places. So you can see Mr Deputy Speaker—and I am sure that the member for Parramatta can see—that the closures of these before and after school care services will only make the situation in Blacktown worse than it already is.

speech.para: I am very pleased to say that the new Labor candidate for Greenway, Ed Husic, is an excellent candidate. He is a young man who has grown up in the area and went to school in the area. He is now campaigning strongly in the electorate, as I am in this parliament. He is going around the electorate doorknocking and meeting the constituents, and this is one of the big issues that people are talking to him about. He is also getting on with the job of campaigning for extra child-care places in the electorate of Greenway. In May this year, Ed invited the Labor shadow minister for family and community services, the member for Lilley, to launch a campaign to force the Howard government to increase child-care places in Greenway, and there has been a good response to the petitions. Further to that, he organised for the Labor shadow minister for children and youth, Senator Collins, to address a child-care forum of providers and parents in the local community. Ed has been telling me about some of the horror stories that he finds while doorknocking—for example, a woman who earns $350 a week in wages and spends $290 on child care. This is a major issue in my electorate. The problem has been caused by the Howard government and it will only be rectified by the election of Mark Latham as the Prime Minister of Australia.

subdebateinfo.title: Flinders Electorate: Koo Wee Rup, Lang Lang and Clyde

talk.start.para: —I want to raise two different issues and both relate to the area of Koo Wee Rup, Lang Lang and Clyde. I would like to firstly talk about the magnificent Koo Wee Rup Primary School. I have been informed by senior members within the school that the school faces two challenges. First, there is a problem in relation to the car parking outside the school, which is, in the words of one of those people, a virtual quagmire every time it rains. I know this because, during my walk around the electorate for juvenile diabetes, I happened to visit the Koo Wee Rup Primary School on a morning on which it was raining, and the car park was a quagmire. There is a very simple solution. The local council, the Cardinia Shire Council, which generally does a great job and of which I am a great supporter, needs to contribute and work on the land outside the Koo Wee Rup Primary School to ensure that it is fully surfaced, with an adequate car park and footpaths for kids to use to get to and from school. It is only a short distance. It is a minor project but an important one to the health of the school.

speech.para: Second, the Koo Wee Rup Primary School also needs maintenance funding from the state government. There is a desperate shortage of maintenance funding for basic school works, whether it is in terms of guttering, paving, painting or simply ensuring that the insulation is appropriate. It is a great school with a tremendous principal, Angela Luke, and a great council. What they need is support from the state for the basics—the absolute bare minimum of maintenance work, which should be done and which the school council and the school community are taking care of themselves, with no support. It should be a priority. This is overdue funding for overdue work which should be carried out immediately.

The second thing that I wanted to raise as regards the Koo Wee Rup, Lang Lang and Clyde region relates to roads. A set of three interconnected roads projects is necessary. I will start with the Clyde-Berwick road. What is needed along the Clyde-Berwick road, a road that I know very well from my own travels in the electorate, is a significant upgrade. The shoulders of that road, which is effectively a major thoroughfare, are disastrous. There have been tragedies over the last few years. Those tragedies, sadly, are at risk of reoccurring. That road needs an upgrade to make sure that the shoulders are safe, that the conditions are adequate and that residents are protected—but residents do not want this road to be turned into a bypass. They want an upgrade, but they do not want a duplication of the road. The appropriate place for the bypass is the stretch of road between Pakenham and Koo Wee Rup. The Koo Wee Rup-Pakenham road should be turned into a bypass. That would be the natural extension of what is currently the development of the Pakenham bypass and the process which is beginning there.

The northern route and the southern route would be connected through a north-south bypass which would go to the west of Koo Wee Rup, going straight past the town, which would remove large trucks which are currently passing through Koo Wee Rup. That would provide safety for Koo Wee Rup by taking trucks off the major streets in the heart of the town, which would also protect the Clyde-Berwick road from becoming a major truck bypass, so it suits both of those communities.

The third part of the equation is the town of Lang Lang, which has seen an increase in the number of sandpits which have developed in the area. As a consequence of that, as McDonald's Track enters Lang Lang from the east, we see a very large number of trucks.
